author: Agencias
title: CCOO ve "insuficiente" el preacuerdo de las ITV y sostiene que serán trabajadores quienes tengan "la última palabra" | Actualidad | Cadena SER
text: Comisiones Obreras ha calificado de «insuficiente» la propuesta de acuerdo presentada este miércoles por la empresa concesionaria de las ITVs gallegas durante un proceso de mediación, aunque ha asegurado que «respetará» la decisión de la plantilla. Así lo confirmado este jueves el responsable de CC.OO. de Industria de Galicia, José Luis López, en declaraciones que publica la agencia Europa Press. De este modo, ha esgrimido que los trabajadores serán los que tengan «la última palabra» respecto a la huelga indefinida que iban a comenzar el próximo lunes las ITVs de la comunidad. «Después del sexto día de huelga, la empresa solicitó una mediación que aceptamos todas las partes y que este miércoles dio sus frutos», ha indicado López. En esta línea, ha esgrimido que este preacuerdo se someterá a una votación de las diferentes plantillas de este servicio y cuyo resultado se sabrá este viernes «a última hora de la tarde». Además, López ha recordado que las demandas de la plantilla giraban en torno a un aumento salarial, a eliminar las diferencias entre el personal de nave y el administrativo, así como dejar de trabajar los sábados. En este sentido, ha asegurado que la empresa no ha accedido al 100% pero ha subrayado «avances importantes» respecto a la subida salarial y a equiparar las condiciones de la plantilla. Sin embargo, ha recordado que la demanda referente a los sábados siempre «enroca» la negociación. De este modo, ha explicado que la oferta de la empresa se basa en eliminar seis sábados del calendario y terminar una hora antes, a las 13.30 en vez de a las 14.30 horas, en los sábados restantes.

author: , Victorville Daily Press
title: Weekend storm system expected to bring rain, strong winds to High Desert
text: The first storm system of the fall is expected to bring rainfall and strong winds to the High Desert and mountains over the weekend. The storm will move into Southern California Saturday night, bringing light rainfall and strong winds at about 35 mph through Sunday, the National Weather Service reported. Most of the rain is expected in Lucerne Valley, Hesperia, and the San Bernardino Mountains. Apple Valley may get a few sprinkles. A fire weather watch will be in effect from Sunday evening through Monday afternoon due to strong gusty winds and low relative humidity levels in western portions of the San Bernardino Mountains and portions of the Inland Empire, mainly the Cajon Pass, weather officials stated. Average high temperatures Saturday through Monday are expected to range from 60 to 65 in places like Adelanto, Apple Valley, Hesperia, and Victorville. Clear skies with high temps in the high 60s are expected in Barstow and Las Vegas. The weather service reminds residents that Daylight Saving Time ends at 2 a.m. PST. Sunday, Nov. 3, as we “fall back” one hour. Daily Press reporter Rene Ray De La Cruz may be reached at RDeLaCruz@VVDailyPress.com. Follow him on X @DP_ReneDeLaCruz

author: CNN
title: Emu named Keith finds forever home after southern Alberta highway stroll
text:
Read full article CBC Emu named Keith finds forever home after southern Alberta highway stroll CBC July 5, 2024 at 1:04 a.m. · 2 min read Link Copied
An emu found wandering near a highway in southern Alberta is now settling into his new forever home and will soon join a new mob, the term for a group of these Australian birds.
"He's doing good," Rianna Smyth told the Calgary Eyeopener on Thursday.
Smyth is with Cobb's Exotic Animal Rescue, an animal sanctuary and adventure park on the northeast outskirts of Calgary.
"I don't know exactly where [the name] Keith came from," Smyth said.
"We put it up to the staff and everybody came up with Keith. It was between Keith and Kevin."
Keith was found near Highway 22X not far from the Red Deer Lake School, south of Calgary, on June 19, a local newspaper reported .
"When he came to us he was quite docile and he still is," she said.
"He's quite friendly. We can hand-feed him, go right up to him. He will match well with most of our [other emus], most of them are pretty calm and pretty docile."
Emus, native to Australia, are most closely related to the cassowary, not ostriches as commonly thought.
They can reach heights of six feet, with Keith measuring five feet nine inches (1.75 metres).
But where did Keith come from?
"Just guessing and no one will know for sure, but some people use emus to guard their property, livestock or even their dogs," Smyth said.
"They are good at keeping away coyotes and other wildlife, so it could have been something like that. Somebody could have had him as a pet. Somebody could have been breeding them for eggs, they have very large eggs. Those are my guesses. They can jump super high and they can run really fast, so he could have been coming from anywhere."
Keith is now loving his forever home on the outskirts of Calgary after being plucked from Highway 22X in late June. (Alberta SPCA/Facebook)
Smyth said Cobb's Exotic Animal Rescue has evolved beyond its modest beginnings.
"We started as a small hobby farm and then we started receiving a lot of rescues organically. So now we house over 300 animals, and about 70 per cent are rescues."
So once Keith is feeling settled, he'll be formally introduced to his new mob of emus — in his new forever home.
